trans-unit.source: Azure AD Connect: Accounts and permissions | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Azure AD Connect: Accounts and permissions | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: This topic describes the accounts used and created and permissions required.
trans-unit.target: This topic describes the accounts used and created and permissions required.

trans-unit.source: Accounts and permissions required for Azure AD Connect
trans-unit.target: Accounts and permissions required for Azure AD Connect

trans-unit.source: The Azure AD Connect installation wizard offers two different paths:
trans-unit.target: The Azure AD Connect installation wizard offers two different paths:

trans-unit.source: In Express Settings, we require more privileges so that we can setup your configuration easily, without requiring you to create users or configure permissions separately.
trans-unit.target: In Express Settings, we require more privileges so that we can setup your configuration easily, without requiring you to create users or configure permissions separately.

trans-unit.source: In Custom Settings we offer you more choices and options, but there are some situations in which you’ll need to ensure you have the correct permissions yourself.
trans-unit.target: In Custom Settings we offer you more choices and options, but there are some situations in which you’ll need to ensure you have the correct permissions yourself.

trans-unit.source: Related documentation
trans-unit.target: Related documentation

trans-unit.source: If you did not read the documentation on [Integrating your on-premises identities with Azure Active Directory](active-directory-aadconnect.md), the following table provides links to related topics.
trans-unit.target: If you did not read the documentation on [Integrating your on-premises identities with Azure Active Directory](active-directory-aadconnect.md), the following table provides links to related topics.

trans-unit.source: Express settings installation
trans-unit.target: Express settings installation

trans-unit.source: In Express settings the installation wizard will ask for Enterprise Admin credentials so your on-premises Active Directory can be configured with required permissions for Azure AD Connect.
trans-unit.target: In Express settings the installation wizard will ask for Enterprise Admin credentials so your on-premises Active Directory can be configured with required permissions for Azure AD Connect.

trans-unit.source: If you are upgrading from DirSync the Enterprise Admins credentials are used to reset the password for the account used by DirSync.
trans-unit.target: If you are upgrading from DirSync the Enterprise Admins credentials are used to reset the password for the account used by DirSync.

trans-unit.source: On-premises Active Directory credentials
trans-unit.target: On-premises Active Directory credentials

trans-unit.source: Member of the Enterprise Admins (EA) group in Active Directory
trans-unit.target: Member of the Enterprise Admins (EA) group in Active Directory

trans-unit.source: Creates an [account](#active-directory-account) in Active Directory and grants permissions to it.
trans-unit.target: Creates an [account](#active-directory-account) in Active Directory and grants permissions to it.

trans-unit.source: This created account is used to read and write directory information during synchronization.
trans-unit.target: This created account is used to read and write directory information during synchronization.

trans-unit.source: Enterprise Admin credentials
trans-unit.target: Enterprise Admin credentials

trans-unit.source: These credentials are only used during the installation and will not be used after the installation has completed.
trans-unit.target: These credentials are only used during the installation and will not be used after the installation has completed.

trans-unit.source: It is Enterprise Admin, and not Domain Admin, to make sure the permissions in Active Directory can be set in all domains.
trans-unit.target: It is Enterprise Admin, and not Domain Admin, to make sure the permissions in Active Directory can be set in all domains.

trans-unit.source: Global Admin credentials
trans-unit.target: Global Admin credentials

trans-unit.source: These credentials are only used during the installation and will not be used after the installation has completed.
trans-unit.target: These credentials are only used during the installation and will not be used after the installation has completed.

trans-unit.source: It is used to create the [Azure AD account](#azure-ad-service-account) used for synchronizing changes to Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: It is used to create the [Azure AD account](#azure-ad-service-account) used for synchronizing changes to Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: The account will also enable sync as a feature in Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: The account will also enable sync as a feature in Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: The account used cannot have MFA enabled.
trans-unit.target: The account used cannot have MFA enabled.

trans-unit.source: Custom settings installation
trans-unit.target: Custom settings installation

trans-unit.source: When using custom settings the account used to connect to Active Directory must be created before the installation.
trans-unit.target: When using custom settings the account used to connect to Active Directory must be created before the installation.

trans-unit.target: If using a full SQL Server, the user must be System Administrator (SA) in SQL

trans-unit.source: By default, creates the local account that will be used as the [sync engine service account](#azure-ad-connect-sync-service-account).
trans-unit.target: By default, creates the local account that will be used as the [sync engine service account](#azure-ad-connect-sync-service-account).

trans-unit.source: The account is only created if the admin does not specify a particular account.
trans-unit.target: The account is only created if the admin does not specify a particular account.

trans-unit.source: Create the AD DS account
trans-unit.target: Create the AD DS account

trans-unit.source: When you install Azure AD Connect the account you specify on the **Connect your directories** page must be present in Active Directory and have required permissions granted.
trans-unit.target: When you install Azure AD Connect the account you specify on the **Connect your directories** page must be present in Active Directory and have required permissions granted.

trans-unit.source: The installation wizard will not verify the permissions and any issues will only be found during synchronization.
trans-unit.target: The installation wizard will not verify the permissions and any issues will only be found during synchronization.

trans-unit.source: Which permissions you require depends on the optional features you enable.
trans-unit.target: Which permissions you require depends on the optional features you enable.

trans-unit.source: If you have multiple domains, the permissions must be granted for all domains in the forest.
trans-unit.target: If you have multiple domains, the permissions must be granted for all domains in the forest.

trans-unit.source: If you do not enable any of these features the default **Domain User** permissions will be sufficient.
trans-unit.target: If you do not enable any of these features the default **Domain User** permissions will be sufficient.

trans-unit.source: Write permissions to the attributes documented in [Exchange hybrid writeback](active-directory-aadconnectsync-attributes-synchronized.md#exchange-hybrid-writeback) for users, groups, and contacts.
trans-unit.target: Write permissions to the attributes documented in [Exchange hybrid writeback](active-directory-aadconnectsync-attributes-synchronized.md#exchange-hybrid-writeback) for users, groups, and contacts.

trans-unit.source: Password writeback
trans-unit.target: Password writeback

trans-unit.source: Write permissions to the attributes documented in [Getting started with password management](active-directory-passwords-getting-started.md#step-4-set-up-the-appropriate-active-directory-permissions) for users.
trans-unit.target: Write permissions to the attributes documented in [Getting started with password management](active-directory-passwords-getting-started.md#step-4-set-up-the-appropriate-active-directory-permissions) for users.

trans-unit.target: Device writeback

trans-unit.target: Permissions granted with a PowerShell script as described in [device writeback](active-directory-aadconnect-get-started-custom-device-writeback.md).

trans-unit.target: Group writeback

trans-unit.target: Read, Create, Update, and Delete group objects in the OU where the distributions groups should be located.

trans-unit.target: If using a full SQL server: DBO (or similar) of the sync engine database

trans-unit.target: Make database level changes, such as updating tables with new columns.

trans-unit.source: More about the created accounts
trans-unit.target: More about the created accounts

trans-unit.source: Active Directory account
trans-unit.target: Active Directory account

trans-unit.source: If you use express settings, then an account will be created in Active Directory which will be used for synchronization.
trans-unit.target: If you use express settings, then an account will be created in Active Directory which will be used for synchronization.

trans-unit.source: The created account will be located in the forest root domain in the Users container and will have its name prefixed with **MSOL_**.
trans-unit.target: The created account will be located in the forest root domain in the Users container and will have its name prefixed with **MSOL_**.

trans-unit.source: The account is created with a long complex password which does not expire.
trans-unit.target: The account is created with a long complex password which does not expire.

trans-unit.source: If you have a password policy in your domain, make sure long and complex passwords would be allowed for this account.
trans-unit.target: If you have a password policy in your domain, make sure long and complex passwords would be allowed for this account.

trans-unit.source: AD account
trans-unit.target: AD account

trans-unit.source: Azure AD Connect sync service accounts
trans-unit.target: Azure AD Connect sync service accounts

trans-unit.source: Two local service accounts are created by the installation wizard (unless you specify the account to use in custom settings).
trans-unit.target: Two local service accounts are created by the installation wizard (unless you specify the account to use in custom settings).

trans-unit.source: The account prefixed **AAD_** is used for the actual sync service to run as.
trans-unit.target: The account prefixed **AAD_** is used for the actual sync service to run as.

trans-unit.source: If you install Azure AD Connect on a Domain Controller, the accounts are created in the domain.
trans-unit.target: If you install Azure AD Connect on a Domain Controller, the accounts are created in the domain.

trans-unit.source: If you use a SQL server on a remote server, the **AAD_** service account must be located in the domain.
trans-unit.target: If you use a SQL server on a remote server, the **AAD_** service account must be located in the domain.

trans-unit.source: The account prefixed **AADSyncSched_** is used for the scheduled task which is running the sync engine.
trans-unit.target: The account prefixed **AADSyncSched_** is used for the scheduled task which is running the sync engine.

trans-unit.source: Sync Service Account
trans-unit.target: Sync Service Account

trans-unit.source: The accounts are created with a long complex password which does not expire.
trans-unit.target: The accounts are created with a long complex password which does not expire.

trans-unit.source: For the sync engine service account, this account will be used by Windows to store the encryption keys so the password for this account should not be reset or changed.
trans-unit.target: For the sync engine service account, this account will be used by Windows to store the encryption keys so the password for this account should not be reset or changed.

trans-unit.source: If you use a full SQL Server then the service account will be the DBO of the created database for the sync engine.
trans-unit.target: If you use a full SQL Server then the service account will be the DBO of the created database for the sync engine.

trans-unit.source: The service will not function as intended with any other permissions.
trans-unit.target: The service will not function as intended with any other permissions.

trans-unit.source: A SQL login will also be created.
trans-unit.target: A SQL login will also be created.

trans-unit.source: The account is also granted permissions to files, registry keys, and other objects related to the Sync Engine.
trans-unit.target: The account is also granted permissions to files, registry keys, and other objects related to the Sync Engine.

trans-unit.source: Azure AD service account
trans-unit.target: Azure AD service account

trans-unit.source: An account in Azure AD will be created for the sync service's use.
trans-unit.target: An account in Azure AD will be created for the sync service's use.

trans-unit.source: This account can be identified with its display name.
trans-unit.target: This account can be identified with its display name.

trans-unit.source: AD account
trans-unit.target: AD account

trans-unit.source: The name of the server the account is used on can be identified in the second part of the user name.
trans-unit.target: The name of the server the account is used on can be identified in the second part of the user name.

trans-unit.source: In the picture above the server name is FABRIKAMCON.
trans-unit.target: In the picture above the server name is FABRIKAMCON.

trans-unit.source: If you have staging servers, each server will have its own account.
trans-unit.target: If you have staging servers, each server will have its own account.

trans-unit.source: There is a limit of 10 sync service accounts in Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: There is a limit of 10 sync service accounts in Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: The service account is created with a long complex password which does not expire.
trans-unit.target: The service account is created with a long complex password which does not expire.

trans-unit.source: It is granted a special role **Directory Synchronization Accounts** which has only permissions to perform directory synchronization tasks.
trans-unit.target: It is granted a special role **Directory Synchronization Accounts** which has only permissions to perform directory synchronization tasks.

trans-unit.source: This special built-in role cannot be granted outside the Azure AD Connect wizard and the Azure portal will only show this account with the role **User**.
trans-unit.target: This special built-in role cannot be granted outside the Azure AD Connect wizard and the Azure portal will only show this account with the role **User**.

trans-unit.source: AD account Role
trans-unit.target: AD account Role
